content:
Hi @T-compiler/meeting; the triage meeting will take place in about 2h
WG-prioritization has done pre-triage in #t-compiler/wg-prioritization/alerts and prepared the meeting agenda

We will have checkins from:

  • @WG-async-foundations checkin by @nikomatsakis and @tmandry : anything to share?
  • @WG-traits checkin by @nikomatsakis and @Jack Huey : anything to share?
Hello @T-compiler/meeting! The triage meeting is starting now. Please leave a :wave: to indicate you're here.
Felix is out today so I'll be running the meeting.

Let's start with a few minutes for

Announcements
Reminder: meeting rustc steering: "guiding principles" doc tomorrow April, 23rd at 10am EST (14:00 UTC)

• New MCPs (take a look, see if you like them!)
    • No new proposals this time.

• Old MCPs (not seconded, take a look)
    • "Add different entry points for x.py" compiler-team#396
    • "rustdoc is using rustc_ast_pretty, would it be possible to make it somewhat "stable"?" compiler-team#403
    • "Eagerly construct bodies of THIR" compiler-team#409
    • "LLVM plugin support in Rust" compiler-team#419
    • "A --temps-dir option for specifying where the intermediate files are written" compiler-team#423

• Pending FCP requests (check your boxes!)
    • "Add default search path to Target::search()" rust#83800

• Things in FCP (make sure you're good with it)
    • "MCP: More Cranelift-friendly portable SIMD intrinsics" compiler-team#381
    • "Uplift the invalid_atomic_ordering lint from clippy to rustc" compiler-team#390
    • "Rename -Cllvm-args to something backend agnostic" compiler-team#421
    • "Update the existing musl targets to be dynamically linked." compiler-team#422
    • "Split rustc_mir" compiler-team#426

• Accepted MCPs
    • No new accepted proposals this time.
  • Finalized FCPs (disposition merge)
    • "Tracking issue for RFC 2457, "Allow non-ASCII identifiers"" rust#55467

WG checkins

@WG-async-foundations checkin by @nikomatsakis and @tmandry

The major work has been the async vision doc.
We now have 30 status quo stories, with more on the way.
We recently announced the start of the shiny future brainstorming session.
If you're interested in participating, you might consider joining one of the writing sessions that are taking place tomorrow, hosted by rylev and nikomatsakis.

@WG-traits checkin by @nikomatsakis and @Jack Huey

We've been concentrating on a number of initiatives:

  • Creating a standalone library for Rust types: Jack Huey recently landed #76814, which refactored binders so that they have a list of the things which they bind. This helps to align with Chalk's representation and permits us to represent things like for<'a> fn(i32), where the 'a in the binder doesn't actually appear in the type. Other notable PRs are on the way.
  • Improving chalk: FireFighterDuck landed rust-lang/chalk#698 that fixes coinductive handling in the recursive solver. Movement here has otherwise been slow.
  • Async fn in traits: We created a project board tracking the major blockers and milestones in this effort.
  • Closing various bugs: most notably, nikomatsakis has been working with Aaron Hill on #83913 and with Jack Huey to resolve some problems that arose aftr #76814 landed.

Office hours: We've also designed some regular blocks ("office hours") where nikomatsakis and others are around and working on tasks. There is one general office hours and the other is designed for async fn in traits. Check the compiler team calendar for details.
Wow, nice to see so much activity in both working groups :tada:
Ok, let's get started. If anyone has an announcement, pm me and I'll make sure we get to at the end of the meeting.

Backport nominations

T-compiler stable / T-compiler beta

  • "move new c abi abort behavior behind feature gate" #84158
    • "PR #76570, which implements the "C-unwind" ABI, also changes the behavior of the "C" ABI, re-introducing the abort-on-unwind logic once more. However, while "C-unwind" is behind a feature flag, the abort-on-unwind logic is not."
    • nomination postponed from previous meeting, @simulacrum suggests asking the project group to come back with a summary of the pros/cons and whys
this is the one discussed last week, right?
Yes, that's correct.
(On related zulip topic, I got confirmation that backport has no expected advantage over revert of original PR)
So my inclination would be to revert on beta, if it can be done easily.
Perhaps we should just revert then.
Yeah
Ok, let's do that. I will leave a comment saying as much on the PR.

• "Update to LLVM 12.0.0 final" rust#84230
    • opened by @cuviper, already merged
    • @Nikita Popov comments we should wait for the backport of https://reviews.llvm.org/D99469 (not landed upstream yet)
    • @nagisa comments that the patch to add dwarf annotation for inline stack probe won't make it LLVM12 final so it will need to be manually backported to nightly/beta
can we approve either/or?
i.e., if the revert of the full PR is not great, just apply the smaller patch?
(to avoid another resync)

simulacrum said:

i.e., if the revert of the full PR is not great, just apply the smaller patch?

Yeah, that makes sense to me.

@Nikita Popov comments we should wait for the backport of https://reviews.llvm.org/D99469 (not landed upstream yet)

It looks like the upstream patch has closed?
Is that phabricator parlance for "merged"?
Yeah, it has been merged, and also backported to our fork lateron.
Great, thanks!
Updating to the 12.0 release makes sense to me.
Does anyone have objections?
Seems not. Approved for beta backport.
so #84230 backported and #84271 declined backport?

• "[beta] Bump LLVM to a upstream 12.0 release" rust#84271
    • opened by @nagisa
    • Current beta branch utilizes a release candidate of LLVM 12.0. We want the upstream fixes (also those we know affecting Rust) before the next stable rust release (May, 6th).
Oh, I see. #84271 is the beta PR for #84230
So #84230 is approved for backport via #84271
By upstream fixes it means pushing our changes to them? If so, those changes wouldn't be part of 12, as that ship has sailed, right?
I believe they're referring to the fixes made in LLVM 12 between the release candidate and the final release.
So they are a part of 12.0
• No stable nominations for T-compiler this time.

T-libs-impl stable / T-libs-impl beta

  • "Fixes API soundness issue in join()" rust#81728
    • opened by @Yechan Bae , already merged
    • nominated by @cuviper because of CVE-2020-36323

Wesley Wiser said:

T-libs-impl stable / T-libs-impl beta

  • "Fixes API soundness issue in join()" rust#81728
    • opened by Yechan Bae , already merged
    • nominated by cuviper because of CVE-2020-36323

is there a way to get more eyes on soundness fixes? that PR sat open for a month before being merged :/
Yeah, I think ideally this would have been nominated and we could have found somebody to review sooner.
I just subscribed @Yechan Bae to this stream - Yechan Bae if you find that soundness fixes are being ignored, feel free to ping another reviewer or a member of the triage team
DPC, Camelid, bstrie all do triage and I'm happy to be pinged as well
As we're still covering T-libs-impl issues, pinging @pnkfelix or myself is also appropriate.
FWIW it's only a soundness fix in the sense that you'd need an intentionally hostile borrow impl; not impossible, but pretty unlikely. So while good to fix, I'm not terribly worried
No opposition to a backport though.
Could we mechanically detect mentions of unsoundness or cve and put those prs on blast?
Hm, maybe
The core fix seems pretty small to me and the test looks good so I'm also inclined to backport.
Backport approved.
Regardless I want a lint for std/core at least that detects these cases in the future
(user-supplied impl invoked twice, basically)

• "Fix double-drop in Vec::from_iter(vec.into_iter()) specialization when items drop during panic" rust#83629
    • nominated by @cuviper because of CVE-2020-31162
    • r'ed by @Mara
  • No stable nominations for T-libs-impl this time.

Wesley Wiser said:

  • "Fix double-drop in Vec::from_iter(vec.into_iter()) specialization when items drop during panic" rust#83629
    • nominated by cuviper because of CVE-2020-31162
    • r'ed by Mara
  • No stable nominations for T-libs-impl this time.

this one also went 2 weeks between being merged and being nominated https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/83629#issuecomment-811994759
I wonder if we could let people set beta-nominated on their own PRs even if they're not in the org?
as long as they're merged maybe, to avoid spam
We don't routinely backport fixes, including soundness fixes, though
I don't think there's a need to accelerate; it doesn't matter when the backport flag is set, really.
hmm ok, I guess I'm just nervous it could have been missed
(I don't see that as a big deal)
Seems self contained as well. Backport approved.

T-rustdoc stable / T-rustdoc beta

  • No backport nominations for T-rustdoc this time.

PRs S-waiting-on-team

T-compiler

  • No PRs waiting on T-compiler this time.

T-libs-impl

  • No PRs waiting on T-libs-impl this time.

Issues of Note

Short Summary

  • 0 T-compiler P-critical issues
    • 0 of those are unassigned
  • 69 T-compiler P-high issues
    • 45 of those are unassigned
  • 0 P-critical, 2 P-high, 6 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-beta
  • 1 P-critical, 3 P-high, 2 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-nightly
  • 0 P-critical, 40 P-high, 86 P-medium, 11 P-low regression-from-stable-to-stable

P-critical

T-compiler

  • No P-critical issues for T-compiler this time.

T-libs-impl

  • No P-critical issues for T-libs-impl this time.

T-rustdoc

  • No P-critical issues for T-rustdoc this time.

P-high regressions

P-high beta regressions

  • "probe-stack=inline-asm generates wrong DWARF information" rust#83139
    • @nagisa handled backporting of https://reviews.llvm.org/D99579 in PR #84270
Should #83139 be closed then?
Or does #84270 need to be backported to beta?
Oh nevermind. #83412 was merged to master not beta so 1.52 should also be unaffected.
Moving on.

Unassigned P-high nightly regressions

  • "Diagnostic when a trait is not in scope no longer tells you to add a use, instead tells you to box the receiver." rust#84272
    • A very useful diagnostic is lost, apparently regressed in commit
    • perhaps happened in PR #83667
    • @estebank suggests a fix but not sure if applicable in all cases
I can take a look at it this weekend. Been tied up lately.
Great, thanks @Esteban Küber!

Performance logs

2021-04-21 triage logs

Another quiet week with very small changes to compiler performance.

Triage done by @rylev. 1 Regressions, 0 Improvements, 1 Mixed, 0 of them in rollups

Regressions

Fix lookahead with None-delimited group #84130

  • Moderate regression in instruction counts (up to 1.4% on incr-unchanged builds of deep-vector-check)
  • While this change fixes a bug, it does introduce moderate regressions in runtime performance on some benchmarks and a fairly large regression on the compilation of the rustc_parse crate itself.
  • We will follow up on this particularly in the matter of rustc_parse's compilation times regressing.

Improvements

  • none

Mixed

Add some #[inline(always)] to arithmetic methods of integers #84061

  • Moderate regression in instruction counts (up to 1.7% on full builds of regex-debug)
  • Moderate improvement in instruction counts (up to -1.3% on incr-unchanged builds of cargo-check)
  • This change inlines a bunch of code that might not have been previously. It's not really a surprise that codegen now is taking longer to churn through all those inline calls.
  • While this tradeoff on compile times for runtime performance is likely worth it, we are checking in with the PR author and reviewer to make sure this is discussed.

Nags requiring follow up

  • This week's follow ups:
    • https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/84130#issuecomment-823898920
But yes, removing that check should make both suggestions come up, the tricky thing is always giving just one correct suggestion.

Nominated Issues

T-compiler

  • No nominated issues for T-compiler this time.

T-libs-impl

  • No nominated issues for T-libs-impl this time.

RFC

  • No nominated RFCs for T-compiler this time.
Wow, no nominated issues at all this week!
I will give one last reminder that we have a steering meeting tomorrow to discuss the "guiding principles" @pnkfelix sent out a few weeks ago. I hope to see everyone there!
With that, let's call the meeting early.
Thanks for attending @T-compiler/meeting. Have a great rest of your week! :smile:

Draft for next week's agenda:
https://hackmd.io/DiNdx3YBQSScLreQNjQWjw?view

Scheduled checkins from @WG-diagnostics and @WG-rustc-dev-guide
